alert.note: Alert for Mesa (Colorado) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS GrandJunction (Western Colorado and Eastern Utah)
info.headline: Flood Advisory issued May 16 at 3:22PM MDT until further notice by NWS GrandJunction
info.description: ...The Flood Advisory continues for the following rivers in Colorado... Gunnison River above Grand Junction affecting Mesa County. .The combination of warm, spring temperatures and the potential for periods of heavy rain falling on a deep snowpack upstream would lead to an increase in runoff from snowmelt. Flows in rivers will continue to increase through the end of the week. ...FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE... * WHAT...Minor flooding caused by rain and snowmelt continues. * WHERE...Gunnison River above Grand Junction. * WHEN...Until further notice. * IMPACTS...At 10.0 feet, considerable agricultural land flooding is likely between Whitewater and Orchard Mesa. Water flows into a quarry on the left bank of the Gunnison downstream the Hwy 141 bridge. At 11.0 feet, water nears the bottom of State Highway 141 bridge and water reaches the bridge near the Redlands Dam. At 13.0 feet, some residential flooding is likely near Redlands Dam. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:30 PM MDT Tuesday the stage was 10.9 feet. - Forecast...The river will fall to 10.7 feet tomorrow morning. It will then rise to 12.5 feet early Saturday morning. It will fall to 12.0 feet early Saturday afternoon. It will then rise to 12.4 feet early Sunday morning. It will fall again and remain below flood stage. - Action stage is 10.0 feet. - Flood stage is 13.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Fld Observed Forecasts (6 pm MDT) Location Stg Stg Day/Time Wed Thu Fri Gunnison River Grand Junctio 13.0 10.9 Tue 2 pm MDT 10.9 11.6 12.2 &&
info.instruction: If you encounter a flooded roadway, turn around and find an alternative route. If you are in the advisory area, remain alert to possible flooding or the possibility of the advisory being upgraded to a warning. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
